column4: how can i get my linux computer to sync up with the workgroup the rest of the (windows) computers are using in the house?
look at fusesmb
i'm sorry, i dont understand :/
install fusesmb from synaptic. It is real easy to use....type 'man fusesmb' after install and it will explain what to do
it will put your workgroups in a folder of your choice..the shared folders on the network should just be part of your folder
i'm not seeing it when i search fusemb on synaptic with all available apps shown
just a sec
it is there...but now that I think about it I downloaded the source and compiled it as there was a problem, but I don't recall if the problem was in ubuntu (my server) or suse (my laptop)
I can pastebin my sources.list if you like.
fusesmb is available in synaptic
is it fusesmb? not fusemb?
fusesmb - two s's
when i search nothing comes up. do i need an additional source?
not sure...give me a sec and I will pastebin my apt sources
http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/51258/    make a backup of your file before using this one!

the file in /etc/apt called sources.list is the list of repositories that synaptic uses to find packages. The pastebin url I sent contains a copy of my sources.list, which includes a repo that has fusesmb. You would need to make a backup copy of your /etc/apt/sources.list and then create a new one with the contents I sent.
it wont let me save the file, said something about insufficient permission
you need to use 'sudo' to edit system files.
open a terminal and type 'gksu gedit /etc/apt/sources.list'
just for education's sake, what does the gk part do/mean?
or does ubuntu use gnomesu? the gksu is a gui frontend to su....opens a nice little window for the passwd
i dont know, whenever i do sudo it asks for the password before doing whatever it is supposed to do in the terminal
right....entering that password gives you system access
